abstract.p: Letter from Heather Deeley (Animal Rights Foundation) on Sept 20 article deplores Seminole Indian tribe's exploitation of alligators to entertain tourists

block.p: Re ''Filling the Job Is Like Wrestling Alligators'' (front page, Sept. 20):

The Seminole Indian tribe of South Florida has made a mockery of its heritage. Yes, Native Americans once captured alligators and kept them alive in captivity until they were needed for hide or meat (so as not to let the meat go to waste in the Florida sun). But wrestling did not become tradition until the tribe went into the carnival business.
Re ''Filling the Job Is Like Wrestling Alligators'' (front page, Sept. 20):

The Seminole Indian tribe of South Florida has made a mockery of its heritage. Yes, Native Americans once captured alligators and kept them alive in captivity until they were needed for hide or meat (so as not to let the meat go to waste in the Florida sun). But wrestling did not become tradition until the tribe went into the carnival business.

Some say an alligator can take a little rough handling, but people who once respected the land and its inhabitants should know one thing: caging and manipulating animals to be exploited for entertainment is nothing to brag about.
HEATHER DEELEY Communications Coordinator Animal Rights Foundation of Florida Pembroke Pines, Fla., Sept. 20, 2000
